title: Jeremiah Imprisoned and Delivered
shortSummary: Jeremiah faces opposition and imprisonment for prophesying the fall of Jerusalem. Despite the princes' hostility, God uses Ebedmelech to rescue Jeremiah, and the prophet continues to faithfully deliver God's warning to King Zedekiah about surrendering to Babylon to preserve life.
timeline: c. 587 BC - The siege and impending fall of Jerusalem during King Zedekiah's reign

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet of God who faithfully delivers God's warnings about Jerusalem's destruction and suffers imprisonment for his message.

keyCharacters.name: Zedekiah
keyCharacters.description: The last king of Judah who struggles with fear and indecision but secretly promises Jeremiah protection.

keyCharacters.name: Ebedmelech
keyCharacters.description: An Ethiopian eunuch in the king’s house who acts courageously to rescue Jeremiah from the dungeon.

keyCharacters.name: The Princes (Shephatiah, Gedaliah, Jucal, Pashur)
keyCharacters.description: Leaders who oppose Jeremiah's prophecies and seek to silence him by imprisonment and death.

definitions.definition: A dark, damp prison cell often underground, used here to describe the pit where Jeremiah was thrown.
Another name for the Babylonians, the empire besieging Jerusalem and destined to conquer Judah.
A man who has been castrated, often serving in royal courts; Ebedmelech was a trusted official in the king’s house.
Thick mud or sludge; Jeremiah sank into this in the dungeon, symbolizing his dire physical and spiritual condition.

outline.heading: The Princes Oppose Jeremiah’s Prophecy
outline.description: The princes hear Jeremiah’s message that Jerusalem will fall and urge King Zedekiah to put Jeremiah to death, accusing him of weakening the people’s morale.

outline.heading: Jeremiah Thrown into the Dungeon
outline.description: Jeremiah is cast into a muddy, waterless dungeon where he sinks and faces death, illustrating the cost of faithful prophecy.

outline.heading: Ebedmelech Rescues Jeremiah
outline.description: Ebedmelech pleads with the king to save Jeremiah, and with the king’s permission, rescues him using ropes and old rags to prevent injury.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Counsel to King Zedekiah
outline.description: Jeremiah warns Zedekiah to surrender to Babylon to save his life and the city, but the king fears betrayal and mockery, yet Jeremiah urges obedience to God’s word.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Secret Communication and Continued Imprisonment
outline.description: Zedekiah instructs Jeremiah to keep their conversation secret; when questioned by the princes, Jeremiah gives a guarded reply and remains in prison until Jerusalem falls.

application: Trust God’s promises even when speaking truth leads to opposition or suffering, as Jeremiah did.
Courageously intercede and act to help those unjustly treated, following Ebedmelech’s example.
Obey God’s word fully, even when fear or social pressure tempts us to compromise, as Zedekiah was challenged to do.
Maintain faithfulness and perseverance in trials, knowing God’s purposes will ultimately prevail.

keyVerses.text: Thus saith the LORD, He that remaineth in this city shall die by the sword, by the famine, and by the pestilence: but he that goeth forth to the Chaldeans shall live; for he shall have his life for a prey, and shall live.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly states God’s warning and promise of life through surrender, highlighting the choice between judgment and mercy.

keyVerses.text: Then the king commanded Ebedmelech the Ethiopian, saying, Take from hence thirty men with thee, and take up Jeremiah the prophet out of the dungeon, before he die.
keyVerses.significance: Shows God’s providential protection through human agency and the king’s reluctant obedience to save His prophet.

keyVerses.text: But Jeremiah said, They shall not deliver thee. Obey, I beseech thee, the voice of the LORD, which I speak unto thee: so it shall be well unto thee, and thy soul shall live.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes the importance of trusting and obeying God’s word for personal and national deliverance.
